<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 349, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0606/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 156, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 730, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 72, 601, 88]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 133, 561, 151]]<|/det|>
# 1. ALGEBRA

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 165, 242, 182]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 195, 386, 212]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 214, 583, 247]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 272, 228, 288]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 291, 752, 330]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 495, 381]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 411, 384, 428]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 433, 536, 465]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\{2a + (n - 1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 488, 336, 505]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = ar^{n - 1}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 509, 430, 544]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r \neq 1)\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 546, 418, 574]]<|/det|>
\[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 611, 594, 628]]<|/det|>
# 2. TRIGONOMETRY

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 643, 158, 660]]<|/det|>
Identities

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 672, 581, 724]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{c}\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\\ \sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\\ \cosec^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 766, 243, 784]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 791, 588, 823]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 826, 594, 848]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 853, 556, 881]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 92, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 76, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
The curve \(y = a\cos bx + c\) , where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers, passes through the points \(\left(-\frac{\pi}{6}, - 2\right)\) and \(\left(\frac{\pi}{9}, \frac{1}{2}\right)\). The curve has a period of \(\frac{2\pi}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 138, 143, 157]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 136, 384, 157]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a, b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 138, 920, 157]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 559, 94]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\), where \(\mathrm{f}(x) = (2x - 5)(x - 1)^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 146, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 685, 125]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary points on the curve \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 440, 146, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 440, 767, 459]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 440, 920, 459]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 470, 846, 816]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 833, 144, 851]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 833, 715, 851]]<|/det|>
Hence find the values of \(k\) for which \(\mathrm{f}(x) = k\) has exactly one solution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 833, 920, 851]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 72, 700, 89]]<|/det|>
In this question, all lengths are in centimetres and all angles are in radians.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 98, 662, 279]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 291, 866, 308]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circle with centre \(O\) and radius 12, and a circle with centre \(C\) and radius 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 306, 918, 323]]<|/det|>
The circles intersect at the points \(A\) and \(B\), such that \(OA\) and \(OB\) are tangents to the circle with centre \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 339, 146, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 339, 747, 357]]<|/det|>
Show that the obtuse angle \(ACB\) is 2.35 radians, correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 339, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 472, 146, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 472, 470, 490]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 472, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 636, 146, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 636, 428, 655]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 636, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 831, 91]]<|/det|>
The function f is such that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = 4\ln (3x - 2)\), for \(x > a\), where \(a\) is as small as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 103, 180, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 103, 405, 122]]<|/det|>
Write down the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 103, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 186, 180, 205]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 186, 403, 205]]<|/det|>
Write down the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 186, 920, 205]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 269, 180, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 269, 527, 288]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\), stating its domain and range.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 269, 920, 288]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 467, 180, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 467, 920, 502]]<|/det|>
On the axes sketch the graphs of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) and \(y = \mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 483, 920, 502]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 511, 845, 866]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 79, 146, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 78, 761, 100]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathrm{g}(x) = (2x + 1)^{\frac{1}{2}} + 4\), for \(x > 0\), solve the equation \(\mathrm{gg}(x) = 9\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 79, 146, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 77, 401, 109]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{1 + \cot^2\theta}{\cot^2\theta} = \sec^2\theta.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 81, 918, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 146, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 574, 381]]<|/det|>
Write down the derivative of \(\tan \theta\) with respect to \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 361, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 483, 144, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 470, 767, 515]]<|/det|>
Using part (a) and part (b), find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \left(\frac{1 + \cot^2\theta}{\cot^2\theta} - \sin\theta\right) \mathrm{d}\theta.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 483, 920, 502]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 84, 96, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 84, 146, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 79, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
Find, in descending powers of \(x\), the first 3 terms in the expansion of \(\left(x + \frac{2}{x^2}\right)^{10}\). Simplify each term as far as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 85, 94, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = \frac{\ln(3x^2 - 1)}{x + 2}\), for \(x > \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\). When \(x = 1, y\) is increasing at the rate of \(h\) units per second. Find, in terms of \(h\), the corresponding rate of change in \(x\), giving your answer in exact form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
The tangent to the curve \(y = \mathrm{e}^{x}(2x + 5)^{\frac{1}{2}}\) at the point where \(x = 2\) meets the \(x\)-axis at the point \(X\) and the \(y\)-axis at the point \(Y.\) Find the coordinates of the mid-point of \(XY,\) giving your answer in exact form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 87, 920, 432]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = \frac{4}{2x + 1}\) and the straight line \(2y = 6x + 1\). Find the area of the shaded region, giving your answer in the form \(\ln a + b\), where \(a\) is an integer and \(b\) is a rational number. [8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 477, 89]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for question 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The first 3 terms of an arithmetic progression are \(2\tan 2x\), \(5\tan 2x\), \(8\tan 2x\). Find the values of \(x\), where \(-180^\circ \leqslant x \leqslant 180^\circ\), for which the sum to 30 terms is \(455\sqrt{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 72, 531, 91]]<|/det|>
The first 3 terms of a geometric progression are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 98, 784, 127]]<|/det|>
\[5\cos^{2}\bigl (\theta -\frac{\pi}{2}\bigr), 20\cos^{4}\bigl (\theta -\frac{\pi}{2}\bigr), 80\cos^{6}\bigl (\theta -\frac{\pi}{2}\bigr), \mathrm{where} -\frac{\pi}{6}\leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{7\pi}{6}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 131, 784, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(\theta\) for which this geometric progression has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 131, 920, 150]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 73, 562, 88]]<|/det|>
